text: STRUCTURAL TEXTURE SIMILARITY METRICS FOR RETRIEVAL APPLICATIONS
Xiaonan Zhao1, Matthew G. Reyes2, Thrasyvoulos N. Pappas1, David L. Neuhoff 2

1EECS Department, Northwestern Univ., Evanston, IL 60208
2EECS Department, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109

ABSTRACT
Traditional image similarity metrics compare two images on a
point-by-point basis. On the other hand, structural similarity
metrics (SSIM) attempt to base image similarity on “struc-
tural” information. We evaluate the performance of SSIM
metrics in the context of texture similarity, and propose new
metrics that incorporate the best features of SSIM and elimi-
nate the most serious drawbacks. We show that the proposed
new texture similarity metrics outperform SSIM and its vari-
ations, as well as PSNR and other traditional metrics. We
demonstrate the advantages of the new metrics on a carefully
selected set of 39 texture pairs and comparisons with informal
subjective test results.
Index Terms— content-based retrieval, texture similarity
1. INTRODUCTION

The objective evaluation of the similarity of two images is of
great interest for a variety of applications, including image
quality evaluation, compression, and retrieval. The focus of
this paper is on texture similarity for content-based retrieval.
In contrast to traditional compression applications, texture re-
trieval is especially challenging because it allows substantial
point-by-point variations in textures that humans judge to be
essentially identical. The goal of this paper is to develop tex-
ture similarity metrics that agree with human perception.
Most existing image similarity metrics compare two im-
ages on a point-by-point basis. This includes both image do-
main metrics, such as peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), and
a variety of metrics that incorporate a multiscale frequency
decomposition, such as DCT, subband, and DWT based met-
rics [1]. The latter can incorporate low-level models of the
HVS. On the other hand, structural similarity metrics (SSIM)
[2] attempt to extract “structural” information from the im-
ages. The intent is to allow substantial point-by-point changes
that do not affect image structure, such as intensity and con-
trast changes, while remaining sensitive to changes that erode
structure, such as blurring and ringing.
SSIM and its derivatives have been shown to perform well
for a variety of distortions, including additive white noise,
blurring, compression artifacts, contract and intensity shifts,
rotations, translations, and zoom [2]. In [3] the performance
of SSIM metrics was examined in the context of realistic dis-
tortions that arise in video coding and transmission applica-

tions.
In this paper, our focus is on texture similarity for
retrieval. We show that the ability of both traditional and
SSIM metrics to predict perceived similarity of texture image
patches is not as satisfactory. We propose new SSIM metrics
that take advantage of the most powerful aspects of the SSIM
approach and improve on its most serious limitations. Exper-
imental results with a carefully selected set of 39 texture pairs
and comparisons with informal subjective test results indicate
that the metric modiﬁcations lead to signiﬁcant performance
improvements. Indeed, we expect that the new metrics will
help in the design of new generation texture retrieval tech-
niques. While our focus is on texture, we believe that the new
metrics will apply equally well to general images.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2
reviews SSIMs. Section 3 proposes new metrics for texture
similarity. Section 4 analyzes the experimental results. The
conclusions are summarized in Section 5.
2. REVIEW OF SSIM METRICS

The SSIM metrics [2] attempt to account for high-level prop-
erties of the human visual system (HVS), but employ no ex-
plicit model of the HVS. As described in [4], the basic SSIM
metric combines three terms: a luminance (mean) comparison
term, a contrast (variance) comparison term, and a “structure”
term. Given two images or image patches (windows) x and y
to be compared, the luminance comparison term is deﬁned as
l(x, y) = 2µxµy + C1

where µx and µy are the means of the two windows. The
contrast comparison term is deﬁned as
c(x, y) = 2σxσy + C2

where σ2

structure term is deﬁned as

where σxy is the covariance between the two windows. C1,
C2, and C3 are small constants. These three terms are com-
bined to give a composite measure of structural similarity:
SSIM(x, y) = l(x, y)αc(x, y)βs(x, y)γ
(4)
where α, β, and γ are positive weights, typically set to 1. The
SSIM is typically evaluated in a small sliding window (e.g.,

7 × 7), and the overall image similarity is obtained as the
spatial average over the entire image. This basic SSIM metric
is sensitive to spatial translation [5].
The SSIM idea can easily be extended to the complex
wavelet domain [5]. The complex wavelet SSIM (CWSSIM)
is computed over a subband of the complex wavelet trans-
form. Note that the wavelet subbands (with the exception of
the lowpass subband) are zero mean, so the luminance term
affects only the baseband calculations, otherwise it is equal to
one. In [5], they set α = β = γ = 1 and C3 = C2/2. The
overall image similarity can then be computed as the average
over all spatial locations and subbands, or over a subset of
the subbands. The CWSSIM implementation provides invari-
ance to small spatial translations, rotations, and scaling. In
addition, it can incorporate perceptual weights that reﬂect the
noise visibility thresholds of the different subbands [3]. In
the experiments of Section 4, we use a 3-level, 6-orientation
steerable ﬁlter decomposition [6].
3. NEW TEXTURE SIMILARITY METRICS

We now propose new SSIM metrics that better account for
perceptual texture similarity. As we saw above, our goal is to
take advantage of the most powerful aspects of existing SSIM
metrics and to improve on their most serious limitations.
One of the most powerful ideas behind the SSIM approach
to image quality is the fact that it moves away from point-by-
point comparisons that characterize traditional metrics, and
instead, bases the comparisons on region statistics. The hope
is that as long as the region statistics are the same, the images,
and in particular the textures, will look the same even though
there may be substantial point-by-point variations. However,
the original SSIM does not fully embrace this new philoso-
phy, as the structure term – the one that actually gives the
metric its name – is in fact a point-by-point comparison. Al-
though the structure term can capture some of the shape dif-
ferences between the two images, it is too constrained to cap-
ture the perceptual similarity of two textures. Thus, we pro-
pose to eliminate the structure term and to replace it with ad-
ditional terms that depend on region statistics.
Our motivation comes from the texture analysis/synthesis
literature. In [7], large texture patches are constructed from
small texture patches in a visually seamless fashion without
even reference to an original texture. It is thus very unlikely
that this extrapolated texture will match the original texture
on a point-by-point basis. Thus, in order to allow signiﬁcant
point-by-pointvariations in the proposed new metrics, we will
drop the structure term. However, as we will see in Section 4,
the luminance and contrast terms are not enough to ensure
the visual/structural similarity of the textures, so we will then
add more terms that depend on region statistics. Portilla and
Simoncelli [8] demonstrated that a wide variety of textures
can be synthesized using a large set of statistical parameters
that characterize the coefﬁcients of a multiscale frequency de-
composition. While the texture analysis/synthesis problem

requires several hundred parameters, the hope is that a much
smaller set will be adequate for texture similarity.
Thus, the main idea is to use a broader set of subband
statistics to account for texture characteristics. Note that the
mean and variance used in the existing SSIM metrics do not
provide any directional information. Although direction is
accounted for implicitly when we compute statistics of sub-
bands with different orientations, we propose adding the ﬁrst
order autocovariance in the horizontal, vertical, and two diag-
onal directions. The autocovariances are then normalized by
the variance to obtain the ﬁrst order correlation coefﬁcients in
the four directions. The horizontal is deﬁned as follows:
ρx(0, 1) = E{(xi,j −µx)(xi,j+1 −µx)}/σ2

The expected value is an empirical average over the window.
The vertical and diagonal terms are deﬁned in a similar fash-
ion. Note that in contrast to the variance, which takes val-
ues in the entire positive real axis, the correlation coefﬁcients
can be negative, and take values in the ﬁnite interval [−1, 1].
Thus, the new comparison terms must take a different form
than those of (1) and (2). After extensive experimentation,
we selected the following formula:
c0,1(x, y) = 1 −0.5 (|ρx(0, 1) −ρy(0, 1)|)p
(6)
which provides numbers in the interval [0, 1]. In this paper,
we set p = 1. The other three terms are deﬁned similarly.
Note that these terms are bounded, symmetrical with respect
to x and y, and have a unique maximum.
We considered adding all four of the new terms to the
SSIM equation, but our experiments indicate that the hori-
zontal and vertical terms are adequate, and that the diagonal
terms do not have a signiﬁcant effect on the results. Thus, the
new structural texture similarity (STSIM) metric becomes:

Note that the exponents sum to one in order to normalize the
metric values so that we can compare metrics with different
numbers of terms. Note also that, with the elimination of the
structure term, the metric values are always positive. This
metric can be implemented in the original image domain or in
the subband domain. The equation above gives an error map,
which can be spatially averaged to obtain an overall similarity
value. As in the original SSIM, we calculate all the parame-
ters in a sliding window over the entire image.
A natural question is whether these image statistics are
adequate for SSIM. For example, one could argue for adding
higher order autocovariances and the corresponding correla-
tion coefﬁcients. Note, however, that computing higher order
autocovariances is essentially equivalent to computing ﬁrst
order autocovariances of decimated images. In order to avoid
aliasing, a much better approach would be to downsample (ﬁl-
ter and decimate) the images and then compute the ﬁrst order
statistics. This naturally leads to a multiresolution approach,
that is, computing the STSIM over the subbands of a multires-
olution frequency decomposition, then combining the results
over both space and frequency.

Once the metric values at each image location of each sub-
band are computed, a natural question is how to combine the
metric values. We considered two approaches:
Approach A: Average over both space and frequency (radial
and angular orientation).
Approach B: Multiply the metric values across frequency
ﬁrst, normalized by taking the m-th root (where m is the num-
ber of subbands), and then take the spatial average.
The advantage of the ﬁrst approach is that it is consis-
tent with the CWSSIM, and that perceptual weights can be
included in a natural way. The advantage of the second is
that the weakest matches tend to dominate (when multiplying
numbers in the [0, 1] interval). For the same reason, in Ap-
proach A, it is important to multiply the different terms ﬁrst,
then do the spatial averaging; otherwise, the localized differ-
ences will be diminished.
4. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS

In order to evaluate the SSIM and proposed STSIM metrics
in the context of texture retrieval, we assembled a comprehen-
sive set of textures that includes natural scenes, man-made ob-
jects, graphic images, and textiles. We selected about 30 tex-
ture patches from the Brodatz set, standard test image images
(e.g., “Lena,” “baboon”), various online texture databases,
and the authors’ photo collection. They were arranged in 39
pairs that include both similar and dissimilar pairs. Some of
these pairs are shown in Fig. 1. In order to obtain a prelim-
inary evaluation of the metric predictions, we conducted an
informal subjective test with four subjects. Figure 1 shows
16 of the 39 pairs along with the subjective scores, in a scale
from 1 to 10, where 10 indicates that the pairs are highly sim-
ilar and 1 indicates that they are completely dissimilar.
Our goal was to compare the proposed STSIM metrics
with the existing SSIM metrics as well as PSNR, and also, to
investigate the need for perceptual weighting (subband noise
visibility). In addition, we compared the two error pooling
approaches we discussed in the previous section. Since our
goal is texture retrieval, instead of measuring correlation of
the metric predictions with the subjective assessments, we
judge a metric by its ability to discriminate between similar
and dissimilar texture pairs. Thus, we consider that a metric
is good if the values it assigns to similar pairs of textures are
consistently above the values it assigns to dissimilar textures.
That is, there is a threshold (or an interval) such that metric
values above the threshold (interval) indicate similarity and
below the threshold (interval) indicate dissimilarity.
In order to make it easier to compare the different ap-
proaches, we implemented a variation of the CWSSIM metric
that is based on a 3-level, 6-orientation steerable ﬁlter decom-
position, with both α = β = γ = 1 and α = β = γ = 1/3. We
also tested the CWSSIM metric without the structure term.
The proposed STSIM metric was computed using the same
decomposition and four terms, as in (7). In all cases, we used
a 7 × 7 sliding window. For all three metric types, we tested

the two pooling approaches, additive (A) and multiplicative
(B). For Approach A, we tried the three algorithms both with
and without perceptual weighting, and found the perceptual
weighting does not help; in fact, it makes things a bit worse.1

Our results for Approach A are shown in Fig. 2. The hori-
zontal axis shows the different textures arranged according to
decreasing subjective score; each texture is assigned an inte-
ger from 1 to 39. The vertical axis shows the metric values.
The vertical dashed line indicates the boundary between the
similar and dissimilar pairs. The horizontal dotted lines show
reasonable threshold values to separate similar from dissimi-
lar textures. Note that (with the exception of Pair 5 discussed
below) the STSIM does the best job at distinguishing similar
and dissimilar textures. Note also that removing the “struc-
ture” term deteriorates the performance of the CWSSIM met-
ric. The two additional terms of the STSIM metric more than
make up for that, however. Another interesting observation
is that for the CWSSIM metric using α = β = γ = 1/3 per-
forms better than α = β = γ = 1. Moreover, the 1/3 power
results in a more reasonable range of metric values, which is
also consistent with the other metric variations.
We should point out that the textures of Pair 5, which
present a special case, are similar at a coarse scale but are
quite different at a ﬁne scale. Thus, the metric values are quite
low. If, however, we use a larger sliding window for texture
analysis, then the metric values become considerably higher.
The results for Approach B are shown in Fig. 3, and they
are good (and comparable to Approach A) for all three met-
rics, irrespective of which terms are included in the metric.
This is because two textures will be dissimilar if they are dis-
similar in one scale and orientation. This is exactly what mul-
tiplicative pooling does: the weakest matches dominate. One
the other hand, Approach A may be more suited for image
compression applications, where the relative ordering of sim-
ilar textures become important. More extensive testing will
be needed to determine the best approach. Finally, we also
tested the basic image-domain SSIM and PSNR. The results
are not shown here, but both have serious limitations and are
clearly outperformed by the metrics shown here. Speciﬁcally,
the SSIM values in all the experiments are in general very low
and do not reﬂect changes in perceptual similarity, while the
PSNR has inconsistent results for several of the test pairs.
5. CONCLUSIONS

We proposed new structural texture similarity metrics that in-
corporate the best features of SSIMs and eliminate their most
serious drawbacks. Our primary focus has been in texture
similarity. We have shown that the proposed new metrics out-
perform conventional SSIM and its variations, as well as tra-
ditional metrics such as PSNR. However, while the proposed
metrics provide a nice threshold for separating similar and
dissimilar pairs, they do not appear to have the same scaling
